self.intro: LLXML: "LLM XML" - A hybrid XML+Markdown format for AI-assisted development. This spec defines itself.
self.philosophy:
Optimized for human-LLM communication during software development: - Token efficiency: terse tags, minimal boilerplate - LLM comprehension: structure models parse naturally - Human readability: clean enough to write by hand - Expressivity: flexible for any domain
Markdown flows inside XML. Tags are short. Structure serves communication, not schema validation.
self.file_types:
Six root tags define file types:
- `` - Architecture spec for something you run (desktop, web, CLI, server) - `` - Architecture spec for something you consume (crate, package, framework) - `` - Teachable process an LLM can learn (workflow, procedure, technique) - `` - Coding conventions and constraints (style, testing, patterns) - `` - External reference material you study but don't own (cloned repos, examples) - `` - A spec that defines itself (inception)
All files share a common header: ```xml identifier What it is or when to use it ```
self.versioning:
Root tags support an optional `v` attribute for version tracking:
```xml
```
Rules: - Whole numbers only, no decimals - Increment when document is finalized, not during iteration - Optional: missing `v` attribute implies version 0 - Soft requirement (tooling may warn, but won't fail)
Bump the version after editing is complete and the document is ready for use.
self.type_notation:
Terse hybrid notation for data structures:
``` struct User { id: i64, name: str, email?: str, # optional (replaces Option) tags: str[], # array (replaces Vec) metadata: str -> any, # map (replaces HashMap) }
enum Status { Pending, Active, Suspended { reason: str, until: i64 }, } ```
Primitives: str, i32, i64, u32, u64, f32, f64, bool, any, u8[]
Avoid: Rust memory types (Arc, Box, Cow), newtype wrappers, language-specific collections.

self.project_layout:
LLXML projects use git worktrees:
``` project/ ├── ll.xml # Manifest (signals "this is LLXML") ├── main/ # Git repository (has .git/) ├── stable/ # Stable branch worktree (for vendoring, optional) ├── _feature-x/ # Feature worktrees (underscore prefix) ├── META/ # Shared dev knowledge (not in git) │ ├── spec/ # Architecture specs │ ├── skills/ # Project-specific skills │ ├── tickets/ # Task workflow │ └── logs/ # Handoff logs └── ctx/ # Assembled context (gitignored) ```
Key concepts: - **main/** is the repo, worktrees reference it - **META/** shared across worktrees, not shipped - **Source** (main/, worktrees) ships when vendored - **stable/** only needed if others will vendor this project
self.vendoring:
Libraries share code via stable worktrees:
```bash git submodule add file:///path/to/library/stable vendor/library ```
"Publishing" = merging main to stable. Consumers get a snapshot via submodule.
self.unified_scanning:
Files categorized by root tag, not path. Location determines shipping: - META/ = dev-time, not shipped - Source = shipped when vendored
Rule: If it helps *build* the thing, META. If it helps *use* the thing, source.
self.styling: - Markdown inside XML flows naturally - Terse tag names: `` not `` - Nest only when semantically meaningful - No XML attributes - use nested elements - Invent domain-specific tags as needed
